Module methanol.testutils
Package com.github.mizosoft.methanol.testutils.io.file

Class WindowsEmulatingFileSystem

java.lang.Object
java.nio.file.FileSystem
com.github.mizosoft.methanol.testutils.io.file.ForwardingFileSystem
com.github.mizosoft.methanol.testutils.io.file.WindowsEmulatingFileSystem
All Implemented Interfaces:
Closeable, AutoCloseable
public final class WindowsEmulatingFileSystem extends ForwardingFileSystem
A FileSystem that wraps another to emulate Windows behaviour regarding deletion of files with open handles. Tracked handles are only those acquired with FileChannels and AsynchronousFileChannels (i.e. using methods like Files::newOutputStream won't run emulation properly).

On Windows, deleting files while they're open isn't allowed by default. One has to open the file with FILE_SHARE_DELETE for that to work. Luckily, NIO opens file channels as such. The problem is when a file is requested for deletion while having open handles, Windows only guarantees it gets physically deleted after all its open handles are closed. In the meantime, the OS denies access to that file. Since Windows associates handles with file names, the deleted file name hence can't be used. Things like creating a new file with the name of a file marked for deletion, renaming another file to such name or opening any sort of channel to such file all throw AccessDeniedException. This file system emulates that behavior so we're sure these cases are covered when interacting with files on Windows.
